that makes it easy to build and run applications that rely on highly connected data sets the core of Neptune
is a high performance purpose-built graph database engine this engine is optimized for storing billions of
relationships and quering the graph with millisecond latency customers frequently ask for assistance on modeling their
data for graphs so we hope this series will inspire on the subject today in episode 4 we'll be
exploring how graph databases can transform your PHOPS practice if you're wrestling with cloud cost management try
and understand complex relationships or looking to make more datadriven decisions about your cloud spending this
session's for you we'll start by breaking down what Finaps really means and no it's not just about cutting costs
then we'll explore why graph databases are particularly well suited for FinOps drawing some interesting parallels with
cyber security solutions i'll show you how many of the same data sources and relationship-based approaches that have
revolutionized the cyber security market can bring new insights to your cloud financial management in late 2023 I
wrote a blog for the AWS database blog describing some of these techniques for
improving state-of-the-art in cloud FinOps and numerous FinOps teams have expressed disappointment that this paper
was only conceptual and there is no software implementing these changes so I'm taking it to the next level in this
video and will demonstrate the data you need and expand on the techniques I covered in that blog in this case I
wasn't able to find any public data sets showing the data we need so I created my own by generating usage in an AWS
account and anonymizing the data using this data I'll show you how we can use it to uncover hidden cost patterns
improve resource allocation and quantify business results in ways that
traditional reporting tools might miss so whether you're starting your Finaps journey or looking to take your
practices to the next level you'll come away with high with actionable insights and practical steps to begin
implementing these concepts in your organization so let's dive in let's start with the fundamentals what
exactly is FinOps it's a combination of finance and DevOps but much more than just a clever name fin is both an
operational framework and a cultural practice think of it as equivalent to the transformative methods that revolutionize software development like
agile but into the world of cloud financial management at its core Fid has
three main objectives first it's about maximizing the business value you get from your cloud and technology
investments this isn't just about cutting costs it's about optimizing the return on every dollar spent second it
enables datadriven decision-m in real time in the cloud world waiting for monthly reports isn't good enough you
need insights when decisions are being made and third and this is crucial it creates financial accountability through
collaboration specifically we call out engineering finance and business teams here PHOPS breaks down the traditional
silos between these groups creating a shared understanding and responsibility for cloud spending this collaborative ex
aspect is what makes PHOPS transformative it's not just another cost management tool it's a fundamental
shift in how organizations think about and manage their cloud
resources this is a critical point I want to emphasize so I'm saying it again when people first hear about FinOps they
often jump to the conclusion that it's just another cost-saving initiative that misses the bigger picture the real goal
of FinOps is to create a culture where you're maximizing the value you get from your cloud investments to drive
efficient growth notice I said efficient growth not just cost reduction think
about it this way sometimes spending more money is exactly the right thing to do maybe you need to overprovision
temporarily to meet a surge in customer demand or perhaps investing in a more expensive managed service will free up
your developers to focus on core business features what Finops does is bring financial accountability to these
decisions it helps teams understand and actively manage the trade-offs between three critical factors: speed cost and
quality for example your development team might choose a more expensive service because it helps them deliver
features faster with FinOps that becomes a conscious informed decision rather than an accidental outcome everyone
understands the cost implications and the business value being delivered in return this culture of financial
accountability doesn't constrain innovation it enables smarter innovation by ensuring everyone understands the
economic impact of their technical decisions you might be wondering what
does all this FinOps talk have to do with graph databases well it turns out that FinOps has a lot in common with an
area where graphs have already proven their value cyber
security think about the questions you need to answer in FinOps you want to understand how resources in your cluster
interact within a given project you need observability and to whether best practices are being implemented these
are very similar to the types of questions we ask in cyber security and just like in cyber security these
questions are fundamentally about relationships relationships between the resources between projects between teams
and between costs let's look at some specific example in PinOps you might
want to know if resources that communicate with each other are consistently tagged this is crucial for accurate cost allocation in cyber
security you'd be asking a similar question about whether communicating resources have appropriate encryption
and permissions or consider observability in PinOps you want to identify successful project
architectures so you can replicate that efficiency in new developments and improve your budgeting in cyber security
you're looking for patterns of secure architectures to replicate across your organization these parallels aren't just
conceptual as we'll see they mean we can leverage similar data sources and similar graph-based techniques to drive
powerful PHOPS insights let's dig deeper into the data
similarities between cyber security and PHOPS and why this approach has proven so effective in graph databases first we
have control plane APIs accessed by the SDK these are crucial in cyber security
for understanding your cost your resource landscape and identifying
potential vulnerabilities in PinOps we can use the exact same APIs to get
visibility into resources and the relationships from an architecture perspective which we can then combine
with our cost and usage reporting to get deeper understanding into where our costs go this allows us to map out how
different parts of our infrastructure connect to and depend on each other and is vital for understanding cost
flows next consider VPC flow logs in cyber security there they are used to
monitor network traffic and detect unusual patterns that might indicate a security threat for PinOps we use the
same data to understand how resources communicate with each other which can reveal insights about application
architecture and resource utilization that directly impact costs finally there's Cloudatch metrics
security teams use these to monitor for anomalies that might indicate a breach in FinOps we use the same metrics to
understand how much our resources are being used this is crucial for identifying underutilized resources
optimizing performance and ultimately again managing costs the beauty of using a graph database for this is that it
allows us to connect all these heterogeneous data points in a way that reveals complex relationships and patterns just as cyber security teams
use graphs to uncover hidden vulnerabilities by connecting seemingly unrelated data points Finops teams can
use graphs to reveal cost optimization opportunities that might be invisible in traditional style of reporting
this quote from Umei Ludwak the CTO of Wiz is particularly
powerful because it comes from one of the leading companies in cyber security when he says "The only way to do this is
by uncovering the toxic combination of risk factors that represents critical risks which we found is only possible

break down why this is so significant in cyber security a single vulnerability might not be critical but when combined
with other factors it could represent a sing a serious risk similarly in FinOps a single expensive resource might not be
concerning but when you see how it connects to other resources influences other costs and impacts the broader
organization you might uncover critical cost inefficiencies that need
addressing and Palo Alto Networks with their extensive experience in security came to the conclusion that only a graph
model could effectively represent and analyze these complex combinations of factors they specifically chose Amazon

now so while the benefits of using graph databases for FOPS are significant it's
important to acknowledge that there are some challenges to implementation i'm going to discuss these openly first and foremost this
approach requires access to sensitive data we need detailed information about our cloud infrastructure which includes
access to list and describe API calls across all services this level of access might raise security concerns and
require careful management of permissions additionally we need access to VPC flow logs these logs contain
information about IP traffic going to and from network interfaces in your VPC while this data is crucial for
understanding resource interactions it's also sensitive information that needs to be handled with care another challenge is that many
PHOPS teams do not have dedicated programmers implementing a graph-based PHOP solution often requires programming
skills to set up data ingestion m create and maintain the graph structure and write queries this could be a hurdle for
teams that are more financeoriented than tech oriented it's important to note that these obstacles are not
insurmountable they could be addressed through careful planning appropriate security measures and potentially by leveraging managed services or
partnering with your organization's development teams the key is to start small perhaps with a pilot project and
gradually build up your capabilities this allows you to demonstrate value while addressing these challenges
incrementally in the next slide we're going to discuss some practical steps you can take to get started on this
journey so I'm going to leave you with a practical road map for getting started with graph-based fin i've broken this
down to five actionable steps that you can begin implementing right away first document your first three critical
queries this week what are the SP spending insights as you'd like to truly transform your decision-making maybe you
want to understand the full cost impact of a specific application including all its dependencies perhaps you need to

implementation fourth challenge your team to find three insights in the graph that your current reporting doesn't

relationships in a new way and finally pick one complex fin use case that's
currently difficult to analyze and try modeling it as a graph this could be something like understanding the cost
